awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Using Notions of Simulation to Explore the Power of Self-Assembling Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
A wide variety of self-assembling systems exist in nature.  These are systems in which complex structures are formed from individual molecules that combine with each other autonomously, obeying only local rules of behavior and without any external guidance or placement.  This process is responsible for the formation of a huge diversity of inorganic structures (such as crystals like snowflakes), as well as numerous biological structures (including cellular membranes and viruses).  Hoping to harness the power of self-assembly to create advanced materials, complex nanoscale structures, and perform molecular computing, researchers have begun developing artificial self-assembling systems.  This work has consisted of laboratory implementations as well as mathematical and computational modeling.
Theoretical computer science has provided numerous insights into the creation and understanding of theoretical models of self-assembly, and these models have provided valuable understanding which has productively guided laboratory experiments.  In this project, the body of work in defining, developing, and comparing the relative powers of theoretical models of self-assembling systems will be extended by the PI.  In particular, the relative powers of various models will be studied by comparing their abilities to simulate each other.  Additionally, the abilities of systems within existing and new models to mimic biological processes such as evolution and immune system behavior will be investigated.

This project is divided into two main components.  The first consists of a series of studies of the abilities of various theoretical models to simulate each other when certain parameters are fixed, especially the so-called "temperature" parameter fixed at 1, making cooperative behaviors difficult or impossible.  Whether or not certain models, again with fixed parameters, are intrinsically universal will also be explored.  Additionally, while most current theoretical work comparing the relative powers of models is concerned with a strong notion of simulation which includes both the productions and dynamics of the simulating systems, relaxed notions which focus solely on the structures produced (i.e. the productions) of simulating systems will be investigated.  While the previous method has produced great theoretical understanding, this new approach is geared toward a more practical understanding which can guide experimentalists desiring to build predefined structures.

The second main component of this project involves work related to studying the abilities of various self-assembling systems to simulate complex and important biological activities such as protein folding, the formation of prion-like structures, self-replication, evolution, and immune system behaviors.  For much of this, an existing model utilizing dynamically changing basic components, the Signal Tile Assembly Model, will be employed.   Further, a new model based on square 2D components which can fold along their boundaries, allowing for the formation of 3D structures by "foldable" 2D building blocks, will be developed and studied, with special focus on their abilities to abstractly mimic protein-like behaviors.

The work will consist of mathematical modeling as well as computational modeling in the form of simulation software.  Results and software, will be made freely available with already existing software and content on www.self-assembly.net.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The work of this project focused on developing new mathematical models of self-assembling systems, as well as exploring the relative powers of those new models and existing models. In basic versions of the self-assembly models, the self-assembling components are square tiles which bind to each other via glues on their edges. Newer models developed and/or expanded upon during this project included those with more complex tile structures (e.g. arbitrary polyominoes, polygons, tiles which can fold into three dimensional structures, etc.), and also models with different dynamics (e.g. tiles which can be reflected and rotated, tiles which can activate and deactivate glues, models allowing hierarchical assembly of arbitrarily large pairs of subassemblies, etc.). Results were proved in these and other models which explored their powers and limitations. Furthermore, notions of simulation were developed to determine the abilities of systems within the various models to: (1) perform universal computation, (2) include tile sets which are capable of simulating all tile sets and systems within their model, and (3) include systems in one model which can simulate arbitrary systems in other models. Such results have further developed the understanding of self-assembly across a wide domain of component types and dynamics, and help to guide experimental work in developing physical implementations of such systems by elucidating which features give rise to which powers.

Large emphasis was placed on the development and exploration of ``dynamic'' models in which tiles can change states or the properties of their bonds with each other. A main goal was to explore how such models could contain systems which exhibit several features of living systems. This led to results showing how systems of universal shape replicators can be developed using signal-passing tiles, a model where two-dimensional tiles can fold to form three-dimensional structures, constructions showing how arbitrary systems within the amoebot model of ``programmable matter'' can be simulated by tile-based self-assembling systems, and constructions showing how to self-assemble arbitrary shapes within a model which abstractly captures the dynamics of cotranscriptional folding.

This grant served as the primary support for two PhD students who each graduated and obtained jobs in academia. It also supported multiple workshops for high school students and research experiences for undergraduate students during each summer of the project, as well as outreach activities in which hundreds of college students volunteered each year to help teach local elementary students the basic concepts of computer programming. It provided support for the work on 15 peer reviewed conference publications and 8 journal publications, as well as content on the web portal self-assembly.net and for newly developed graduate courses.


Last Modified: 10/24/2019
Modified by: Matthew Patitz
